subdebateinfo.title: Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Legislation

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. I want to test the teeth in this sell-out, now Democrat endorsed, environment bill. On page 9 of the bill there is provision that any company which takes action which is likely to have a significant impact on world heritage is liable to a penalty of $5.5 million. In view of the advice of the minister's own departmentâ
âMadam President, I raise a point of orderâ
âI am listening to the question and there are some aspects with it that cause difficulty. I would like to hear the whole question.
âMy point of order is that he cannot ask the minister a question about the billâ
âThat is correct, and that is why I am listening very carefully to it.

âIn view of the departmental advice to the minister that the proposed roads and forest harvesting operations in the Huon and Picton valleys of Tasmania are a significant adverse impact on the current Tasmania wilderness world heritage area, is the minister, with the passage of this bill, going to take action, with that $5.5 million penalty in hand, against the woodchip corporations which are causing that significant adverse impact on world heritage?
âThe first part of the question clearly deals with a clause of the bill and is out of order. The second part of the question may have some matters in it that I refer the minister to.

âAt the risk of being ruled out of order in answering the second part, it is true that the new scheme for national protection of the environment includes designating areas of national environmental significance. For the first time in the history of this country, there will be direct triggers, rather than indirect triggers that are linked to irrelevant activities. One of the areas of national environmental significance which appeared to be obvious to me was matters that are world heritage listed. At present there is no such process. At present there is no Commonwealth trigger in an activity that takes place in a world heritage area simply because of the fact of its location. So I would have thought that Senator Brown would have seen a positive step forward.

answer.para: I hope that within his question there is a hint that he recognises that for the Commonwealth government to take responsibility for world heritage in this way is something that he might like to commend. It is a first step for the Commonwealth to designate areas of national environmental significance and accept a Commonwealth responsibility for their protection, and then to work hand in glove with state governments that are dealing with their areas of environmental protection to deliver an overall better national outcome. That is what this government is seeking to achieve, and it is good that those who want to work constructively with this governmentâsome of the green groups, for example; the Australian Democrats and othersâhave come on board and asked what can be delivered. They might ask for more, but what can be delivered is a significant step forward in the protection of our natural environment.

Instead of just pulling stunts, today could be a day for Senator Brown to finally turn the corner and say he wants to contribute to a better outcome. He could actually vote for it. He might even come in here for the first time with suggestions to improve it. Of course, we asked him whether he wanted to engage in a consultation process, and he knew better and had no wish to do so. He has never wished to work with government towards a better environmental outcome and in his years in this place he has never delivered one better environmental outcome. That must be a matter of great disappointment to his constituency. I would have thought that they sent him here to get better environmental outcomes. Never once, with all the influence he has got of a very valuable vote, has he been prepared to negotiate to achieve a better environmental outcome. All he wants to do is pull a stuntâclimb a tree, fall in front of a bulldozer and hope he gets on the evening news. But it is too late. Real environmentalists have gone forward and are actually improving the outcomes on the ground, and Senator Brown has been left behind.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister ducked that; I will ask him to be more direct with this one. He mentions the Democrat cooperative approach. I ask the minister: did the Democrats approach the government to ensure that global warming would be a trigger in this legislation? Did they also approach the government to get clearance of native vegetation as a trigger? Did they ask the government to establish a commissioner for the environment? I ask the minister: on all three key Democrat counts did they fail and are their actions in trying to put a gloss on this disastrous legislation for the people of Australia more akin to the actions of a politician of the past called Quisling when it comes to the Australian environment?
âSenator Hill, if there are any aspects of that you can comment on without debating the legislation before us, you may do so.

âIt is largely boring and irrelevant. The point is that the billâobviously Senator Brown has not read the billâis an implementation of a COAG agreement which sets out areas of national environmental significance and it allows for further areas to be listed by means of a consultative process. In relation to global warming, Senator Brown is two weeks behind the game because the government, out of another negotiation, has announced that it is prepared to enter into that consultation process with stakeholders. So, Senator Brown, it is just a pity that you did not come to the government and suggest such an initiative. If you had done so you would not be so irrelevant.

subdebateinfo.title: Member for Leichhardt: East Trinity Development

talk.start.para: âI direct my question to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Is the minister aware of a report released by the CSIRO earlier this year which reveals that some of the worst acid and heavy metal pollution in the country is to be found on the east side of Trinity Inlet near Cairns? Is he aware that this is also the site for the proposed NatWest East Trinity Development, which will house up to 20,000 residents and include 15,000 square metres of retail development? Did Mr Entsch inform the minister that he owns two investment properties near the development site? Did he inform the minister that, if the development goes ahead, he is set to make a significant profit on his own project?

âThe answer to the first question is no. The answer to the second question is no. The answer to the third question is that I cannot confirm that matter; it will have to be checked after question time. On the fourth question, I have no knowledge of any alleged investments by Mr Entsch at the alleged site.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister saying that he has not read the CSIRO report? It may well beâI understand arrangements in portfoliosâthat that has been delegated to someone else. I would like him to at least confirm that he has neither read the report nor received, if you like, a submission on the basic contents of the report. I would like that established before we take this any further.
âI have not read that report.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. I refer to the decision by the federal government to proceed with the Albury-Wodonga freeway and I ask: (1) does the projected costing for the internal route for this freeway include all costs or does the government expect there will be further costs incurred in the design and construction stages; (2) do the current estimates include social and health costs; (3) has a full costing of the alternative external route been done and is this costing available to the public; (4) is the government aware that the majority of Albury residents are opposed to the internal route for the freeway; and (5) should this freeway be renamed, as the internal route through the middle of Albury could not be called a `bypass'?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âI am aware that a road through and by Albury is a contentious issue. I am aware there was a demonstration or gathering outside Parliament House yesterday which, I understand, Senator Woodley and Senator Allison attended. I also understand that the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, left an important cabinet meeting to go out and speak with the people who had some concerns about that particular issue.

answer.para: Senator, wherever there are different routes for roadways you get conflict and differences of opinion. I assume it is no different in the Albury area. The proposed route of the road through Albury-Wodonga is one that the Albury City Council has been lobbying successive federal and state governments for for over 30 years now. The member for Farrer, the Deputy Prime Minister, and Mr Lou Lieberman, the member for Indiâjust on the other side of the borderâboth support that internal route. As well, the Liberal state member for Albury, Mr Ian Glachan, also supports that route and he was just recently re-elected to his seat. So, Senator, when you say the people of Albury are opposed to it, I cannot imagine that is right when all three elected people representing the area support it and their support is well known and they continue to be re-elected.

I am sorry I did not write down the precise questions, and if I miss some of the specific questions you have raised, Senator, I will try and get you answers to themâbut you did raise the question of budgets and money. In the last budget we provided $7 million for further preconstruction works, such as investigation and design; preparation of tender documents; and land acquisition for the construction of this major project. In fact, your colleague Senator Lyn Allison went through this in some detail at the recent esti mates committee. The New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority is the main planner of this area. Both the New South Wales government and the Victorian government in fact support the internal route but the New South Wales government has the responsibility for route selection and associated planning and environmental considerations. They are a state responsibility in the first instance. I am not trying to buck-pass: we the federal government accept what both state governments have said in relation to this.

The proposed route, we think, will have a lot of benefits. It will result in a massive improvement in the amenity of the residents along the existing route. It will remove the traffic problems currently affecting the commercial and residential areas of Albury. Even if the external route were built, it would provide very little benefit to the residents of Albury because nearly 90 per cent of the traffic along the existing route would still enter Albury, so I am told. Senator, you would be pleased to knowâas would your constituents or the people who approached you yesterdayâthat extensive measures are being taken to reduce the visual and noise impact of the route. Senator, I appreciate your concern. You are representing a view of some of the people of the Albury area, but I do not think it is a majority. This proposal has been reviewed any number of times and we think we are right. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I do thank the minister for his answer. However, I wonder, Minister, if you are aware that despite three elections, as you point outâand it is always a debate about whether a mandate applies to specific items in terms of electionsâfour polls have shown that a majority of the residents of Albury are opposed to this route? Secondly, is the government aware that in most other states road construction avoids internal routes, even through small country towns? That is certainly true in Queensland, as you would know, and I cannot understand why the government is supporting the building of an internal freeway through Albury when most road authorities avoid such out-of-date, unhealthy and dangerous options.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âWhy we are supporting the internal route is that it has been investigated any number of times by any number of independent and other authorities. It is supported by the two governmentsâNew South Wales and Victoriaâand the Albury City Councilâand my own department. It has been the subject of very wide consultation with the people of Albury and, all in all, all of the experts and all of the authorities believe that it is the right one. I know you do not want me to give a dissertation on polls and opinion polls and mandates but, when you say that a poll of Albury people opposes it, you have to ask what the question was and how many actually responded to the poll. As we always say in this business, the only poll that really counts is on election day. This was a big issue both in the recent federal election and in the state election; it was a very big issue and candidates who were supporting it were elected by their constituencies. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Member for Leichhardt: East Trinity Development

talk.start.para: âI address my question to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill. Have the activities of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Mr Entsch, in support of the proposed development at East Trinity near Cairns been drawn to the attention of the minister? Was the minister, his staff, his department or the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority invited to participate in the recent bus trip around the proposed development site with Mr Entsch and the developers? âI knew that there was an acid sulphate issue and I understood that there were papers to be released on it which would better inform us all of the extent of that problem and hopefully what remedial action might be taken. Otherwise, I do not recall matters relating to a bus trip around Cairns. That might be something that Senator Reynolds was involved in, as a senator from Far North Queensland. In relation to GBRMPA: yes, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is concerned about damage and potential damage to the reef from acid sulphate resulting, in turn, from developments up the Queensland coast. It is a complex issue. There is a growing awareness of that fact and the science is improving on what are the direct and indirect consequences that can flow therefrom. That is all interesting background but I am not sure it is the political point the honourable senator is wanting to make. It is a bit sad in fact that she has been dragged into this exercise because I thought she was someone of higher standing.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the minister has attempted to answer the second part of my question but my supplementary is: has Mr Entsch had any contact with the minister in relation to the proposed development?
âI do not know what development you are talking about.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Minister, earlier this month the government announced that it had allocated over $1.4 million since November 1996 to the trustee of Mr Skase's bankruptcy to help him recover Mr Skase's overseas assets. Minister, could you please inform the Senate as to the present position with respect to Mr Skase?

âI thank Senator Knowles for her question. She is correct in identifying that we did confirm, during the budget estimates hearings, that the federal government is continuing to fund the trustee to pursue Mr Skase's assets. The funding of $1.45 million is the extent of the Commonwealth's commitment in this matter in respect of completed activity. The federal government's funding has allowed the trustee to conduct overseas investigations in countries including the United Kingdom, Spain and the Cayman Islands and applications for injunc tive relief in Australia, the Cayman Islands, the United Kingdom and Spain, and the court examination in 1998 of the United Kingdom lawyer. The government is continuing in its commitment to pursue Mr Skase in addition to its commitment to fund his trustee in bankruptcy. We will not let him, by any act of omission on our part, obviate his obligations as a bankrupt under Australian law. However, it would be inappropriate for me to give any details at this stage of further activity being undertaken by the trustee.

answer.para: Senators can be assured that the Spanish authorities remain committed to ensuring that the current expulsion proceedings are appropriately resolved in accordance with Spanish law. Mr Skase was notified by the Spanish authorities in October 1998 that his application for residency had been denied. The Spanish authorities presented Mr Skase with a formal order. Mr Skase has appealed against that order. Even if he loses his current appeal to the Spanish Administrative Court, he still has a further right of appeal back to the regional Superior Court. The government stands ready to seek his extradition from a country other than Spain. It bears repeating that it is not possible for us to reopen extradition proceedings in Spain. What I want to do at this point is put on record the Australian government's appreciation of the continued firm commitment from the Spanish government to ensuring that the current expulsion proceedings are appropriately resolved in accordance with Spanish law.

As to Mr Skase's health, we have all seen media reports of Mr Skase's recurring health problems. I am notâand Australian authorities are notâin a position to comment on media reports of his health, beyond noticing, as we all do, that the reports appear to increase as the legal steps associated with his removal from Spain proceed.

talk.start.para: âThat has a ringing familiarity.
âLike someone else we know.

âAustralian doctors have never had the opportunity to properly examine Mr Skase. Skase has consistently refused requests for an examination from the time of the original extradition proceedings. However, I would also make the point that Australia is naturally prepared to arrange for his direct return here on a properly equipped medical evacuation jet should he be sensible enough to decide that the time for fighting this is over and it is time for him to come home. We will provide a properly equipped medical evacuation jet to bring him home. The advice I have is that that evacuation would be at least as safe as the conditions under which Mr Skase is presently residing in Majorca. I conclude by saying, in response to some of the interjections from the other side, that those people who gave him a 10-year passport, who let him get away in the beginning, who failed in their extradition proceedings to bring him back to Australia and who released Federal Court documents in relation to this matter have no business interjecting whatsoever.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Public Housing

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. I refer to the new public housing measure included in the government's GST deal with the Democrats. I ask whether the minister can confirm that last week she told state housing ministers that:

question.para: Additional funding in respect of the impact this will have on state housing authority revenue has been agreed between the Commonwealth and the states and territories. I intend now to gazette the draft agreement which has been amended to reflect this additional funding.
Can the minister inform the Senate precisely how much additional funding the Commonwealth has agreed to provide the states as compensation for this measure?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThere is additional funding available for the states in respect of the impact of taxation reform on public housing. The amount was $269 million and the Commonwealth invited the states to decide on how best it could be divided between them. I have not yet heard whether they have been able to reach agreement. The last time I heard they were finding it impossible to agree and were suggesting that they should come back to the Commonwealth and have us determine it.

âI thank the minister for her answer. I have a supplementary question as a result. Can the minister explain why the Treasurer, on 2 June, told the House of Representatives that the government will not dip any further into the surplus to fund the new public housing measure in his GST deal with the Democrats? I believe he also confirmed today in question time that the government is not engaging in additional claims for housing from the states. Can the minister explain the difference between the answer she has provided to the Senate and the answer provided by the Treasurer?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI think it is a question of the timing of when each was announced. The $269 million was announced before 2 June.

âMy question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill. The coalition government's establishment of the $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust has assisted in restoring and enhancing our land and water resources. What are the additional benefits for the environment following the further privatisation of 16.6 per cent of Telstra?

âIt is another win for the environment because a further $250 million will be invested by this government in remedial work and also in putting in place processes designed to avoid mistakes that have been made in the past. The Natural Heritage Trust is the largest investment in our natural environment, our natural assets, in the history of this country. The Howard government is very proud of it. The amount of $1.25 billion is now to be topped up with another quarter of a billion dollars in a way that no previous government has ever invested our capital. If the sale of two tranches of one capital asset, which is what we are talking aboutâa telecommunications companyâcan be sold and in part deliver this fantastic environmental outcome, it is a further good reason for that sale.

answer.para: One thing that particularly pleases me about the Natural Heritage Trust, which also draws a contrast between now and the way that the conservation groups practised in the past, is the way in which we are able to support the community on the ground in rectifying its own mistakes, in remedying the damage that has been done. So rather than governments just preaching, or conservation groups just protesting under the Bob Brown banner, what we now have are so many community organisations going out there and remedying the mistakes that have been made.

In fact, under the Natural Heritage Trust in just over two years we have already spent half a billion dollars which has supported more than 6,500 individual projects around Australia. That is very different from the way in which this country approached its environmental problems in the past. So yes, I am pleased that out of the sale of a second tranche of Telstra we will be able to make another substantial capital investment in our natural resource base. We have set up the Natural Heritage Trust, we have invested $1.25 billion, we now have another quarter of a billion, we have negotiated and agreed the arrangements with the statesâfor Senator Bolkus's benefitâthrough which most of these programs can be delivered, we set up the advisory group at the advice of the Senate to oversee the development, under Sir James Hardy, of the Natural Heritage Trust Advisory Committee, and we have established the community based state and local assessment bodies that can give us the best advice as to how the money can be spent on the ground to give the best outcomes for each and every dollar.

I take the opportunity to give particular credit to the over 4,000 Landcare groups and other community based environment groups that are doing all this hard work on the ground. They are not launching themselves on the Prime Minister's car as a protest because they are too busy out there pulling weeds, planting trees and repairing damage that has been done. How often has Senator Bob Brown been out there pulling the weeds and planting the trees? Never. He is too busy protesting. The real environmental movement has moved on from the days of confrontation to delivering better outcomes on the ground. Anyone who wants to join that partnership with government is welcome to do so. It is a pity that Bob Brown and the remnants of his environmentalâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Bob Brown to you.

âSenator Bob BrownâI sometimes wonder, I have to sayâand the remnants of his environmental movement are not prepared to do so as well. How are we spending the money? We will invest $430 million in native vegetation and farm forestry; $380 million will be invested in our inland waters and wetlands. (Time expired)
âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

subdebateinfo.title: Member for Leichhardt: Disclosure of Interests

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âYesterday I took some questions on notice from Senator Faulkner to the Minister for Defence. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ
SENATOR FAULKNER, asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, on 21 June 1999:

Is the Minister aware that Mr Entsch has stated that Mr Rod Corey, the head of the Defence Estate Organisation, `unwittingly misled' the Senate estimates committee the week before last? Can the minister inform the Senate in what respect Mr Corey allegedly unwittingly misled the Senate? What action has the minister taken, as the minister in the chair at the estimates hearing, to ensure that the public record is corrected at the earliest opportunity.
SENATOR NEWMANâThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In view of the media comments attributed to Mr Entsch, it is presumed that the Senator's question relates to the issues of whether or not written quotations were received and whether Boral had been contacted for the works at RAAF Base Scherger.

Based on the information available to Mr Corey at the time of the Senate Legislative Hearings on 8 June 1999, it was his understanding that written quotes were not obtained, Defence had received a verbal quote from Cape York Concrete and Defence had only referred to a current Boral price list.

It is now apparent that both Boral and Cape York Concrete were contacted on 9 March 1999 by Sergeant Goddard. As a consequence, Cape York Concrete provided a written quote and Sergeant Goddard concluded from Boral's verbal response that it was uninterested in the project.

On 24 March 1999, Flight Sergeant Jones took over from Sergeant Goddard. Additional quantities of concrete were required for the works and Flight Sergeant Jones approached Cape York Concrete for a revised quote. Flight Sergeant Jones did not approach Boral given its earlier response as conveyed by Sergeant Goddard. A written revised quote was received from Cape York Concrete on 31 March 1999.

Mr Corey did not knowingly mislead the committee. His evidence was based on the best information available and this is reflected in his responses to the Senator. Additional information provided to the Senator on 21 June 1999 to Questions on Notice from the committee should clarify the outstanding issues.

subdebateinfo.title: Ministerial Code of Conduct
Member for Leichhardt: East Trinity Development

talk.start.para: âDuring question time I said that I would call for a copy of the Prime Minister's ministerial guidelines and answer the question asked by Senator Faulkner. The relevant provision, which is self-explanatory, states:

speech.para: Ministers are required to resign directorships in public companies and may retain directorships in private companies only if such company operates, for example, a family farm, business or portfolio of investments, and if retention of the directorship is not likely to conflict with the minister's public duty (eg, a minister should question the retention of a directorship in a company in which share holdings extend beyond the minister's own family).
That might not have been the answer Senator Faulkner wanted, but that is the guideline as laid down by the Prime Minister.

I want to add one point to the answer I gave to Senator Reynolds. I have been reminded that we, being the government, supported the attendance of two CSIRO scientists at a conference on acid sulfate soils in the Cairns region and that we also had an officer from Environment Australia attend that conference.

subdebateinfo.title: Member for Leichhardt: East Trinity Development

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill), to questions without notice asked by Senators Faulkner, Cook, Ray and Reynolds today, relating to the financial interests of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources (Mr Entsch).

I thought it might be useful to provide some brief background to the questions which were asked of the minister in question time today, given that the government ministers seem particularly ignorant about these matters. The truth is that Mr Entsch bought two lots of land at Koombal Park on East Trinity Inlet, jointly with his wifeâthat is, 400 metres up the road from a 700 hectare block that the British banking company Natwest hopes to develop. Although he bought the land for $26,000, the unimproved capital value of Mr Entsch's recent acquisitions was $195,000 in October 1996.

In September 1998, the Cairns City Council changed the East Trinity development control plan to relax planning controls along the East Trinity foreshore, giving this Natwest plan a very new lease of life. The proposal currently has a couple of stumbling blocks which are lack of accessâyou can only get there by water taxi or by a round-about roadâand the severe acid sulfate leaching and other soil toxicity problems that have been raised in question time today.

If the Natwest development goes ahead, it will house up to 20,000 residents and include 15,000 square metres of retail. In time, it will also necessitate the building of a bridge between the Cairns CBD and the new suburb opposite, further adding to the value of Mr Entsch's holdings. What the opposition is concentrating on is what occurred after the election last year because Mr Entsch became Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. On 2 April this year, in that capacity, Mr Entsch launched a CSIRO study into acid sulfate on the Natwest site and told the Courier-Mail:
The only economically viable option might be to allow Natwest to go ahead with its development plans.
That is in the paper. The report gives another option. It says:
It's likely that viable management strategies are available for rehabilitation, including reflooding.

Then you have the workshopâperhaps Senator Hill had officers there. Who knows? There was a workshop on the acid sulfate problem, sponsored by Mr Entsch, using the services of CSIRO to discuss an initial site investigation that they had carried out on the Natwest site and ways of dealing with the acid sulfate soil problem, which we acknowledge is a serious issue. Mr Entsch told the Cairns Post on 20 May this year that the Commonwealth is sponsoring further monitoring by CSIRO and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in Senator Hill's portfolio.

The stench of Entsch just gets worse and worse. There is nothing wrong with a local member pushing for economic development in his electorateâwe know that every local member does that. But when a local member is the parliamentary secretary and can use the good offices of his own portfolio organisationâthat is, CSIROâto look into the potential of East Trinity, and when that same parliamentary secretary has investment properties up the road which depend on the development happening, we say that is not just an altruistic concern of a local member. We have concerns that it is a capital-C conflict of interest. Mr Entsch is obviously desperately trying to find a way to ameliorate the acid sulfate soils problem using CSIRO, desperately trying to promote the NatWest project which will inevitably lead to a bridge bringing his property within a few minutes drive from Cairns. But the Prime Minister, as weak as he is, as incapable as he is of exercising moral authority, should deliver to the Australian public what everyone has been waiting for: some leadership. Mr Entsch must be stripped of his parliamentary secretaryship this afternoon. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI appreciate that it must be very difficult for this opposition at the moment. Here we have Australia in an economic circumstance where it is the envy of the world. Having inherited a deficit of over $10 billion, in just three years this Howard government has turned the economy to prosperity, prosperity particularly envied within our region. This prosperity has been achieved through good policies of soundly restraining expenditure, reforming industrial relations laws, privatising assets that are no longer appropriate in public hands and using the money to repay debt, keeping down interest ratesâthe lowest level in 30 yearsâkeeping down inflation to a stable and historically low level, giving the opportunity for Australians to prosper and, in particular, bringing the unemployment rate down to the lowest level it had been before we had the recession that was inflicted upon us deliberately by the former Labor Prime Minister, Mr Keating.

speech.para: The government is delivering so many benefits to the community as a whole, the latest of which we trust will be implemented in the next few days, and that is fantastic tax reform for this country. That tax reform will finally deliver to us a contemporary taxation system with $12 billion of reductions of income tax to put in place even more incentives for small business to grow, to invest and to provide jobs. It will give particular benefit to exporters to address the current account difficulties which Senator Cook reminds us of so often and get rid of the wholesale sales tax that is so inefficient and cumbersome and, with all the other benefits, get rid of the poverty trap so that all Australians can benefit in that way. The tax reform will provide a capital base from which governments in the future can deliver the services that are reason ably required for Australians, whether they be health, education or any such fields.

In such circumstances as these, one can understand why an opposition would be desperate to find some issue that is irrelevant to the rest of Australia but on which they hope they can get a headline or two. We saw that demonstrated in the stunt from Senator Faulkner in his presentation a moment ago. We all picked the grab that he hopes will be the one on the television tonight.

He tried to trick meâall right, I suppose that is part of the game during question timeâon what the rules are that the Prime Minister has set down in relation to directors. He got that wrong and I suspect he has got a lot of other things wrong as well. Okay, Mr Entsch, we concede, made a mistake and did not list his directorshipsânot a big mistake, because he had actually listed his shareholdings. We know that Labor members on the other side made the same mistake. I did not hear Senator Cook accuse them of using the dopey defence. And when Senator Richardsonâformer minister in this placeâforgot that he was a member of a board that ran a radio station, Senator Cook did not come in here and say, `He is entitled to the dopey defence.' Of course, there is one set of rules for the coalition and another set of rules for the Labor Party.

Nothing has been demonstrated against Mr Entsch that would suggest in any way that there has been improper behaviour on his part. He made a mistake. He owned up to the mistake. The Prime Minister accepted the explanation, because it was a reasonable explanation in the circumstances

What this opposition ought to do, instead of trawling in the gutter in this way, is to start looking at some questions of policy, to start organising itself into an opposition that might one day be capable of governing again, to set itself some goals to do better than when it was last in government, to develop its policies, to get some new blood on the frontbench, and give some of the newcomers a go, because I am sure they could do better than the tired lot that sit on the front bench in this place. When that starts to happenâand I do not care whether it is the new way, the second way or the third way: it is good to see there are a couple of backbenchers wanting to make a difference, and it is a pity that the leadership of the Labor Party, including Senator Cook, cannot pick up the challenge as wellâthen the Labor Party will start to be relevant, and then the Australian people will see that they are at least entitled to consideration. But whilst they just continue trawling in the gutter on irrelevancies they will not be seen as relevant. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âImagine that last contribution. Imagine that Senator Hill was able to speak for five minutes without breath. What a transformation from half an hour ago to now. He could not answer anything at question time. He would not even take it on notice, but eventually he didâ`I'll go and make inquiries.' Suddenly, half an hour later, he is voluble. But what he is doing is defending Mr Entsch on the first set of charges. Today there is a new set of charges, so he is playing catch-up.

speech.para: If Senator Hill wants to lecture us on our behaviour in this place, one of the crucial responsibilities for opposition is to hold governments accountable. The main reason that Senator Coonan and everyone else in the Howard government want to change the Senate rules is not about legislationâthey can usually stitch up a sleazy deal with a few opportunists; that is never hard. They hate the scrutiny. They hate being held accountable.

In this case, we are entitled to ask questions about Mr Entsch's behaviour. We are entitled to ask why, when he was bringing down that CSIRO report, he put that fantastic spin on it. This is a serious report; it goes to the problems of the East Trinity area. Who other than Mr Entsch would have the gall to say that the only way you solve those problems is to put on a massive development; that 13 million cubic feet of topsoil was needed to raise it all by about four feet; and that a bridge be put straight across to the CBD of Cairns. In spite of the fact of all the defence facilities and the oil and sugar facilities further on, you are going to whack a bridge right across it. Mr Entsch is into that. He was referred to in the other place today as the Bob Jelly of the north.

talk.start.para: âOrder! Please do not reflect upon a member.

âThis is SeaChange all over again; this is reality reflecting fiction. What we have, obviously without the knowledge of his senior minister Senator Minchin, is this particular parliamentary secretary trying to use a proper scientific report to get this massive development going. What is the advantage to him? His property is up the road. Once the bridge goes in and once the development starts there, his property is going to go through the roof.

speech.para: Ask yourself how he got it so cheapâmost people know. Most people know what the auction process was on this occasion. Sure, he did buy the land before he went on the front bench, and so buying the land is legitimate; but he cannot use his front bench position to then enrich himself. He is the one that convenes the workshop on the area. Guess what: after the workshop, they have a bus that does a tour of all the development area. I do not know if they stop at the ex-caravan park that Mr Entsch owns, but a lot of people get on the bus. Most of the Queensland government people do not get on the bus, because they are awake-up. They know that something stinks about this particular issue, and so they do not get on it.

The answers that we have received today, admittedly without notice, shed no light on this at all. What Senator Hill did today was defend his past crimes, not his current ones. This is the second strike and, if anyone thinks there will not be a third strike, do not bother. One of my pleas is to those people in North Queensland: stop sending us information on Mr Entsch. We cannot deal with it all at the moment. It is flooding in, and it shows Mr Entsch as an unscrupulous businessman in the north of Queensland.

talk.start.para: âOrder! Please do not reflect upon a member of the other house.

âMadam Deputy President, let me say that the information coming in from North Queensland does not do Mr Entsch any credit in any of the business dealings he has been involved in. The Senate and the other place have only been told about one-tenth of it so far. Many other issues are now emerging as to his behaviour. Sure, I do not mind, I do not take offence when Mr Entsch refers to us on this side as `sewer rats', but I tell you what: when this is all over, it will be Sewer Rats 10, Mr Entsch nil. If you have got form like he has got form, you will be held accountable.

speech.para: No amount of bluster and bluff by Senator Hill is going to stop us from pursuing these issuesâand the Prime Minister on them. The Prime Minister simply will not enforce any code of conduct whatsoever. It is just the Wild West rules that are being applied here. Mr Howard is too weak an individual to actually discipline people such as Mr Entsch that misuse their position. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe only thing that I could agree with in relation to the contributions from Senator Faulkner and Senator Ray is the self-description of Senator Ray as a sewer rat.
âOrder, Senator! I have asked other senators not to reflect upon other members, so please do not continue this reflection.

âMadam Deputy President, I trust you will ensure that that is the course that you adopt with those on the other side. Last night, we had a fantastic result in relation to the further 16.6 per cent sale of Telstra. What do the Labor Party do in response? Devoid of any alternative policies for this country, they jump straight back into the gutter where they wallow, thinking that somehow, if they dredge around enough, they might be able to convince the Australian people that they ought to be entitled to govern this nation again.

speech.para: Of course, whenever they jump back into the gutter and trawl around, the thing they cannot overcome is the political corpse of the former leader, Mr Keating. If ever there was a conflict of interest in this nation, it was while Senator Faulkner and Senator Ray sat around the cabinet table, undoubtedly fully aware of Mr Keating's outrageous involvement in a piggery and his involvement with the Indonesian contactâwith not a word from those two senior cabinets ministers in relation to Mr Keating not even disclosing his pecuniary interest in the matter.

At least Mr Entsch put it on the table for everyone to see that he had a pecuniary interest. Where was Mr Keating's declaration of a pecuniary interest in relation to the piggery? In fact, he lied to the parliament. He denied his involvement, and it has now been revealed that in fact he did have such an involvement and such a pecuniary interest. These people opposite still idolise Mr Keating as supposedly a great leader of this country. Well, if you want to apply some sort of standard to the parliamentary secretary Mr Entsch, why is it that you did not even think about applying that standard to your former leader? Why don't you stand up and have some credibility and say, `We now agree that Mr Keating lied. He should have disclosed his interest in the piggery'?

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, on a point of order: that is an unparliamentary reflection.
âHe is no longer a member of the parliament.
âOrder! I will rule on the point of order. I do not need any help, Senator Abetz.
âMadam Deputy President, my point of order is that that is an unparliamentary reflection on a distinguished member of this parliament.
âHe is no longer a member of parliament, therefore there is no point of order.

âThe Australian people, through that intervention by Senator Cook, have yet again witnessed how the Labor Party will jump to Mr Keating's defence. Senator Cook, of course, was a senior minister of that government sitting around the cabinet table knowing about Mr Keating's piggery involvement and getting involved with Indonesia.
âYou're the liar.
âSenator Cook, will you please withdraw that.
âWithdrawn.

âIf he did not know about the piggery involvement, it indicates that the Prime Minister of the time, Mr Keating, made no declaration whatsoever. Those in the Labor Party, those opposite, have the choice now to let us know whether they knew about the financial interests of their former Prime Minister. If you did, you sat here in guilty silence all along knowing that the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, was lying to the parliament and you did not raise one word of objection to it. Where does that leave those opposite? Without any feathers to fly with in this debate. But, more tragically for the Australian people, you have no policies to fly with either.

speech.para: That is why question time after question time you waste the time of this parliament with motions to take note of answers. You waste the time of this parliament in trawling through the gutter because you have no policy positions to put before the Australian people. You seek to regain office by besmirching people rather than coming forward with good, sound policies. The challenge for people like Senator Ray, Senator Faulkner and indeed Senator Cook is not to trawl through the gutter. I suggest to Senator Cook that in his contribution he talk about policy and how he would like to improve the economic wellbeing of this nation.

talk.start.para: âI will not be provoked by Senator Eric Abetz in his smearing of a distinguished Prime Minister of Australia in order to try to deflect parliamentary attention from his colleague, the parliamentary secretary to the Department of Industry, Science and Resources, Mr Warren Entsch, and his alleged improper behaviour and certainly his proven failure to comply with the Prime Minister's code of conduct. Before the last election, the Prime Minister said he was going to introduce into Australia a higher level of public probity. The Prime Minister broke down his own standards time after time after time as more and more members of his own frontbench were caught in contravention of the terms of that code of conductâin contravention of its explicit terms as well as the spirit of that code of conduct.

speech.para: In the case of Mr Warren Entsch, what has been the defence? The defence for Mr Entsch has again been articulated today by the Leader of the Government in this chamber, Senator Hill, when he said that Mr Entsch made a mistake in filling out his forms, that he inadvertently filled out his forms improperly. What is this person who cannot fill out a form in which he is supposed to set out his pecuniary interests? This person is the parliamentary secretary to the Department of Industry, Science and Resources, a central parliamentary department in the running of this nation. He is someone who is charged with overseeing industry policy for all industry in Australia, someone charged with working with the minister helping to deliver outcomes for the science community of Australia and someone with a view on resources and resource development of Australia.

The defence for Mr Entsch is that he cannot fill out a parliamentary form. This is the dopey defence: he was too damned dumb to be able to do it right. If he is not guilty of being, in this case, misleading, he is guilty of being dopey and he should not be occupying a high office in this parliament and discharging responsibilities on behalf of Australian taxpayers, because he has not got the native cunning just to know where to put his name and how to write down the companies for which he is an owner or shareholder.

Senator Ray said that he is very much like Bob Jelly, the mayor of Pearl Bay in the TV series SeaChange. I remind the chamber that by ironic coincidence the actor who plays Bob Jelly in SeaChange is John Howard. But the Prime Minister, John Howard, who is a different person from that actor, has in fact acted away from his own standard of conduct. Let me quote from the Melbourne Sunday Age of 13 June, just last weekend. An article by Shaun Carney, the political correspondence for the Melbourne Sunday Age, is headed `Howard's code is cracked.' He begins:

So now we know. Unless a frontbencher in the Howard Government is, say, caught on video sticking up a 7-eleven, perhaps sporting a black-and-white striped T-shirt and black mask in the style of the McDonald's hamburglar just for effect, resignation is out of the question. Sounds ludicrous, of course, but so does virtually everything the Government has said and done in its defence of parliamentary secretary Warren Entsch.
The next paragraph reads:

The case against Entsch, half-owner of Cape York Concrete, which won a $175,000 contract with the Defence Department in far north Queensland is open and shut. By failing to disclose his directorship of the company and two others, he breached the Prime Minister's code of conduct, plain and simple.

Plain and simple, Madam Deputy President, he breached it, but will the Prime Minister defend his own code of conduct? Will he demand satisfaction? Will he sack his parliamentary secretary? No, he has defended him. Therefore, he has devalued that code of conduct, devalued integrity in public office, devalued probity on behalf of frontbenchers in his own government, and devalued as a consequence the standing of his government and the institution of this parliament. There is now only one way out for the Prime Minister, in view of the disclosures on the Trinity Bay fiasco adduced in the questioning in question time today where Mr Entsch is a compliant player in providing approval for a development he has a financial interest in. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAs my colleague Senator Calvert, the Government Whip, will attest, we know only too wellâhaving served in coalition for 13 years in opposition, long and cold as it wasâthat these moments of personal attack upon a frontbencher and the chance perhaps to get a scalp are great moments of politics. They get your own side excited, they even get the media excited, and they sustain your troops through those long years in opposition. We know that only too well.

speech.para: But the opposition have to ask themselves: are the likes of Senators Cook, Ray and Faulkner going to get them into government? Is this issue really cutting it out there in the public? The answer to both is no. Is there any substitute for policy? The answer is no. So, in the final analysis, the oppositionâif they want to get into government; if they want to start making inroads into this government's credibilityâought to start on the policy front, because this week alone is going to be a momentous week for the government.

Last night we passed the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 , to sell 49 per cent of Telstra, and with that came a $1 billion package for rural and regional areas. Later on this week, or perhaps early next week, we will be passing the most significant tax change in this countryâsince Federation, ever. We have done it through a very tortuous path and with agreement with the Democrats, with the opposition completely out of the play. With that tax change we will start to reduce the former Labor government's debt. Both are major reforms within one week. And what is the opposition doing? What is their target? What is their focus for the whole week? An attack on a frontbencher in the hope of getting a spurious scalp.

They are attempting to establish that the standards in this parliament have lowered. When we came into government, they were never so low. In fact, the previous government as a wholeâand none less than Senator Cookâwere lying to the Australian public.

No less, they went to the election saying that they had a surplus, when they did not. We had to introduce a Charter of Budget Honesty, which is now recognised throughout the world. In political legend and political lexicon, there was the sports rorts affairâthe whiteboard affair. You cannot go to a political meeting where that is not made fun of and a joke is not raised in that particular area. We had a Prime Minister who could not fill in his own tax form on two occasions. So when it comes to establishing parliamentary standards, I would say the parliamentary standards have well and truly been lifted.

speech.para: In relation to Mr Entsch, you have to look at the core issues of concern. Did he use his position to influence? The answer to that is no. Did he gain financially? The answer to that is no. Were the proper tender procedures undertaken by the defence forces? The answer to that is yes. Was there any conflict of interest with his particular portfolio? The answer to that is no. Where is the Labor Party on the High Court constitutional issue? They seem to have backed off from that at 1,000 miles an hour; it is no longer raised. Are you going to take Mr Entsch to the High Court? That is no longer an issue.

They have scooted around looking for something else against Mr Entsch. The reason for that is there is only one case that they can use as precedent back in 1975âthe Webster case, which happened to be about a former National Party senator. It is quite obvious how the High Court would interpret that. It wouldn't interpret on a narrow basis.

It has to be reasonably established that there was knowledge, there was involvement and there was remuneration. In other words, you have to use a commonsense approach, and that is why the Labor Party have backed off in relation to the High Court and constitutional questions. That is why they are ferreting around looking for other issues in relation to Mr Entsch. The truth of the matter is that the code of conduct cannot be so threadbare as to not include people who come into this parliament with business acumen and business background.

The speech read as followsâ

We are fast approaching the centenary of the establishment of our Federal Parliament. Just as the last decade of the 19th century witnessed impassioned debate on the matters concerning the constitution and the nature of the two houses in the soon-to-be Federal Parliament, so too do we witness renewed debate on these issues as the 20th century draws to a close. But the similarity in the topics is only superficial; for the nature of the discussion is as different and divergent as the century or so that has passed between.

In the 1890s, our Constitutional debate was not about becoming a republic or remaining a constitutional monarchy. It was about turning a group of disparate colonies into a working federation. The debate over the form of the Senate at the time was closely linked to what our forebears apparently envisaged the role of the states in that federation would be. That debate culminated in a limiting of the powers of the larger colonies, New South Wales and Victoria, and gave the colonies equal status as States of the Commonwealth. If we fast-forward to the late 1990s, we find debate about power is still with us, only this time it is about the powers of minor parties and independents. This bill will allow the Senate, the House of Representatives and the wider community to consider the issues involved. The bill provides for the division of States into Wards for the purpose of choosing senators. It will limit the opportunity for minor party members and independents to exercise power far beyond the extent of their electoral support.

I have been considering the issues in this bill for some time nowâthat it corresponds with contemporary public debate on the role of the Senate is merely coincidental. The contentious issues in the current debate include the question of a "mandate", "fair representation" and what it means to review government legislation. Reference is still made to the importance of a "states' house" as the founding fathers would have intended the Senate to be versus the current existence of a partisan approach to the review of legislation proposed by the Government in the House of Representatives. While the presence of independent senators from time to time has given us a glimpse of how the Senate could work in favour of specific statesâand perhaps to the detriment of othersâthe Senate now is party-based and it is this reality with which we must deal. Thus the division of States into Wards as proposed by this bill will more accurately reflect the contemporary mechanisms of this Houseâit merely seeks to formalise and acknowledge what, in actual fact, is really happening in our "House of Review".

In the context of the present debate, several suggestions have been canvassed regarding the possible electoral system on which the Senate is based. I consider that this bill is a concrete step towards the pursuit of Senate reform. I will outline the main features of this bill.

Section 7 of the Constitution states, among other things, that "The Senate shall be composed of senators for each State, directly chosen by the people of the State, voting until the Parliament otherwise provides, as one electorate." The parliament has not otherwise provided and senators are therefore chosen by the people of the various Statesâand now the Territoriesâeach voting as one electorate.

The Electoral Amendment (Senate Elections) Bill 1999 proposes to alter the manner in which senators are elected to the Senate. Rather than represent the State as one electorate, the bill provides that each of the states is to be divided into six Wards, each ward having two representatives in the Senate. The representatives will still be regarded as Senators for the particular State in which their Wards exist. At a periodical half senate election, each Ward would return one senator for that State while at a Senate election following a dissolution, each Ward would return two senators. The bill does not alter the method of selection of Territory senators. At a Senate election following a dissolution, senators would be chosen using the current system of proportional representation, but at a half-senate election preferential voting, as currently used for House of Representatives elections, would be relied upon. It is proposed that ticket voting be retained for both types of elections in order to minimise the possibility of informal votes where a large number of candidates is involved.

The bill also makes consequential changes to the administration of the electoral system. The Australian Electoral officer in each State retains primary responsibility for administration of the Ward system, including the establishment and maintenance of separate Ward rolls. The Australian Electoral Officer is empowered to make whatever arrangements are necessary to maintain the rolls. It is envisaged that this would involve administrative arrangements with the divisional Returning Officers to ensure that information acquired by DROs in the course of their maintenance of divisional rolls is passed on to the Australian Electoral Officer for corresponding action in relation to the Ward rolls. The bill also provides for some modifications to the existing forms for nomination for the Senate.

As the expansion of the administrative structure required to administer the Ward system is untested, the bill provides that the establishment, maintenance and use of Ward rolls will be reviewed by the Australian Electoral Commission five years after the commencement of the act and a report of the review will be tabled in both Houses of the Parliament.

The bill also provides for transitional arrangements. Senators holding office at the commencement of the act will continue to represent their States as a whole for the remainder of their terms of office. It will be necessary for the initial distribution of each State into Wards to be undertaken as a first step to implementing the system. If a Senate election is held before a buffer period of twenty-one days has elapsed after this distribution process is completed, the transitional provisions provide that senators will be elected in accordance with the current system. Any casual vacancies occurring in relation to the places held by senators representing States as a whole would be filled on the same basis.

There is some argument that section 15 of the Constitution, as changed by the Constitution Alteration (Senate Casual Vacancies) 1977, entrenches direct elections of senators by the people of a state as a whole. It is not entirely clear whether section 15 precludes the appointment of a person by a State Parliament to represent a Ward, as opposed to the State as a whole. To safeguard against this possibility, item 17 of the bill provides that a senator appointed to a casual vacancy in a State is deemed to represent the Ward in respect of which the vacancy arose, for the purposes of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.

Section 13 of the Constitution requires the Senate to decide who shall be "long term" and "short term" senators following a dissolution of the Senate. In part, that section provides that "the Senate shall divide the Senators chosen for each State into two classes, as nearly equal in number as practicable; and the places of the senators of the first class shall become vacant at the expiration of three years, and the places of those of the second class at the expiration of six years, from the beginning of their term of service".

The decision of which Senators are to be "long term" and "short term" is the untrammelled right of the Senate. It is expected, however, that should the proposed legislation in this bill be passed, in any future dissolution of the Senate, the new Senate would choose one senator from each Ward to be a senator of the first class and the other senator of that Ward to be a member of the second class.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

The statement read as followsâ

Madam President, I am delighted to be tabling Report 21, Five Treaties Tabled on 16 February 1999 . This report contains the results of the review by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties of the following proposed treaties:
. a treaty on extradition with South Africa;
. a treaty with Sweden on mutual assistance in criminal matters;
. an agreement with New Zealand on the status of visiting defence forces; and
. two defence agreements with the United Statesâthe first concerning the reciprocal provision of logistic support, services and supplies, and the second concerning communications services.
In each case we support the proposed treaty and recommend that binding action be taken.
Our comments on the extradition treaty with South Africa represent a continuation of our support for the negotiation of modernised extradition arrangements.

The key element of these arrangements is that the country requesting extradition has only to provide the other country with a statement of the conduct of the alleged offences by the accused. This is a far more flexible and effective basis for extradition than the traditional arrangements, which require the provision of material sufficient to demonstrate a prima facie case against the accused.

It is important to note that the treaty with South Africa, like all modern arrangements, balances this flexibility by allowing the requested country to refuse extradition in circumstances where either the extradition, or the punishment arising from any conviction, would infringe the civil, political or human rights of the accused person.
The treaty on mutual assistance in criminal matters with Sweden also represents an improvement to our international network of law and justice arrangements.

Mutual assistance treaties play a valuable role in ensuring that law enforcement agencies are able extend their reach beyond national borders. Without such arrangements, the task of investigating and prosecuting trans-border criminal behaviour is complicated immeasurably.
The proposal to conclude a status of forces agreement between Australia and New Zealand is another step in maintaining the long-standing and close defence relationship between the two nations.

While it can hardly be argued that the agreement is a central plank in our defence relationship, the establishment of a standard scheme for the rights and obligations of visiting forces will secure a firm footing for two of the important elements in a healthy defence relationshipâthe exchange of personnel and participation in joint exercises.
In our view, Australia's national interest is also well served by the two defence agreements with the United States canvassed in our report.

The agreement on the reciprocal provision of logistic support, services and supplies (known as the Acquisition and Cross-servicing Agreement) is a standard form agreement that the United States Government is seeking to negotiate with all of its major defence partners.

The agreement establishes rules for the reciprocal provision of support and services in `combined exercises, deployments, operations and for unforeseen circumstances and exigencies'. The agreement will update an agreement initially signed in 1990, during the Gulf War.

The Agreement on Defense Communication Services clarifies the division of responsibility for the provision of on-line communication services between the Australian Defence Force and the United States military. This agreement is substantially the same as the expired 1989 agreement on the same subject and involves an annual expenditure, by Australia, of only $10 000.
Both agreements contribute to our broader strategic relationship with the United States and are important to the extent that they clarify our mutual understandings, expectations and requirements.
I would like to thank my committee colleagues from both sides of the House, and in the Senate, for their continuing commitment to the work of the Treaties Committee.
I commend the report, and its conclusions, to the Senate.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: âI move:

para.inline: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ

The bill is central to the Government's intention to ensure that funding for programmes aimed at improving the situation of Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities is distributed on a needs basis. It will allow the Commonwealth Grants Commission to report on the distribution of funding for meeting the needs of indigenous people. It will also further the Government's aim of improving the situation of Australia's indigenous people by ensuring that an independent assessment of their need for services and programmes is undertaken.

The intention of the Government in taking this important step in providing a better basis for the distribution of funding for indigenous affairs was announced as a commitment during last year's election campaign. The new approach is designed to increase the confidence that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities have in the distribution of funds because it will give them greater assurance that the distribution is based on need.

The Commonwealth Grants Commission is a world-renowned agency that has, until now, been restricted to measuring the relative needs of the States and Territories for untied Commonwealth funding, and to advising on the needs of the small Island Territories. Its expertise in assessing the relative needs of different communities has been underutilised and this bill enables it to be asked to examine the needs of indigenous people.

The Grants Commission is an independent statutory authority and has always acted with absolute freedom in making its recommendations to Government. During an inquiry into the distribution of resources for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander programmes, it will need to have close contact with the Departments and agencies currently involved in deciding the distribution of funding for those programmes, but it will continue to operate with its traditional degree of independence.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will be given opportunities to make both written and oral submissions to the Commission, and to show it the magnitude of their problems. This approach is in line with the Government's commitment to work with ATSIC and the wider indigenous community to develop arrangements to improve the allocation of funding, and to give the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people every chance to discuss their situation with those directly involved in advising the Government.
I commend the bill.
