The speeches read as followsâ
A NEW TAX SYSTEM (FAMILY ASSISTANCE) (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1999

This bill complements the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Bill 1999 that has already been introduced into the parliament. That bill, which forms part of the fundamental reform of the Australian tax system, introduces reform and improvements to the assistance currently provided by government to families. From 1 July 2000, gone will be the 12 conflicting and overlapping family payments. Instead, there will be three well designed, harmonised and generous benefits that will make a positive impact on the living standards of Australian families, particularly those with low incomes.

The A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) bill 1999 contains administrative, procedural and technical rules that will apply in relation to the new family assistance paymentsâfamily tax benefit part A, family tax benefit part B and child care benefit. The bill will also include machinery type provisions dealing with two other family-related payments, maternity allowance and maternity immunisation allowance.
I consider that it might assist this House if I were to provide an overview of the delivery of the family assistance package.

para.inline: A new `Family Assistance Office' will be set up to help families

speech.para: The new Family Assistance Office will deliver family tax benefit (parts A and B), child care benefit, maternity allowance and maternity immunisation allowance. The law does not refer to the Family Assistance Office as it will be a `virtual' organisation using the existing infrastructure of Centrelink, the Australian Taxation Office and the Health Insurance Commission (Medicare Offices). It is expected that all Australian Taxation Offices, all Centrelink offices and all Medicare offices will have a Family Assistance Office as part of their office. The extended network of sites will ensure families have a greater choice about the way in which they access assistance.

In order to give families these choices, the Secretary to the Department of Family and Community Services will have the power to delegate his or her powers to constituent agencies of the new Family Assistance Office. The heads of these agencies and their staff, as delegates of the Secretary, will be able to process claims, make payments and perform other functions under the family assistance law.

para.inline: Making a claim for Family Tax Benefit

speech.para: The primary carer will be able to make a claim for family tax benefit in one of the following ways:
lodge a claim with the Family Assistance Office (through Centrelink) for fortnightly payments; or

claim a lump sum payment at the end of the year (through the taxation system), either through the primary carer's tax return or their partner's tax return. Families will have a further option to reduce their (or their partner's) tax instalment deductions during the year in anticipation of their end of year family tax benefit lump sum entitlement.

para.inline: Making a claim for Child Care Benefit

speech.para: Families will be able to claim child care benefit for formal care (in approved child care services) in one of the following ways:

as instalment payments paid directly to their nominated child care service to enable the service to reduce the fees that the family will pay (current arrangements under which child care assistance advance payments are made to child care services will be preserved for child care benefit purposes. This will be achieved by regulations); or
as a lump sum after the end of the financial year (from the Family Assistance Office).
Child care benefit for informal care will be claimed as a lump sum for a period of care of up to 12 months and paid via the Family Assistance Office.
Child care benefit will not be delivered through the tax system because of the complexity of the information parents would need to retain to be able to correctly assess their entitlement.

para.inline: Making a claim for Maternity Allowance and Maternity Immunisation Allowance

speech.para: Families will be able to claim single, one-off payments of maternity allowance and maternity immunisation allowance from the Family Assistance Office (through Centrelink).
Like child care benefit, maternity allowance and maternity immunisation allowance will not be delivered through the tax system.

para.inline: Families will receive their correct entitlement to family assistance

speech.para: Families who choose to receive fortnightly payments will estimate their income for the current financial year. Their estimated income will be compared with their actual income at the end of the year. Families who have overestimated their income during the year and have been underpaid will receive a `top up' payment at the end of the year. On the other hand, families who have underestimated their income and have been overpaid, will be required to pay back the amount they were overpaid during the year. This is much fairer than the current arrangements for family allowance where families who underestimate their income are required to pay back the amount they were overpaid but families who overestimate their income during the year do not receive a top up payment. It is also fairer than the current arrangement for child care assistance where families do not receive a top up payment if they are underpaid, and are not required to pay back overpaid amounts.

para.inline: Administrative arrangements for Maternity Allowance and Maternity Immunisation Allowance

speech.para: The administration of these payments will not change significantly under the new family assistance regime.

para.inline: Administrative arrangements for Family Tax Benefit and Child Care Benefit will be simplified
Simpler rules will be administered by one agency

speech.para: Rather than dealing with potentially 12 forms of assistance with different eligibility rules and payment arrangements through three different agencies, families will now have to deal with only 3 payments with similar eligibility rules and with one agency, the Family Assistance Office.

para.inline: Same rules for all families

speech.para: There will be one set of rules for all families regardless of how they choose to receive family assistance. For family tax benefit, this means that regardless of whether families receive fortnightly payments or as an end of year lump sum claimed with their tax returns, they will all be subject to the same eligibility criteria, rate calculators and administrative arrangements under the family assistance law. For child care benefit, regardless of whether families receive ongoing payments or lump sum payments from the Family Assistance Office (through Centrelink), the same eligibility rules and rates will apply.

Under the new arrangements, decisions made by the Secretary regarding entitlement to, or eligibility for, family tax benefit and child care benefit will be reviewable by the Secretary, or an authorised review officer, regardless of delivery option. It is expected that where family tax benefit is paid through the tax system, the Commissioner, as delegate of the Secretary, will carry out the review functions for those customers. There will be further rights of appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court. Rules explaining the process for review of decisions are set out in Part 5 of this bill and will be kept separate from the Australian Taxation Office appeal and review process. Determinations made by approved child care services regarding child care benefit in special circumstances will not be reviewable. Approved child care services and registered carers will also have the right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal about the Secretary's decisions affecting them, except where the decision is the result of a Commonwealth planning strategy affecting the distribution of child care places.

para.inline: It will be easier for families to repay overpayments

speech.para: As family tax benefit is partly administered through the tax system, overpayments of family tax benefit will be recovered from a claimant's tax refund where possible. This bill will also allow another person, for example the claimant's partner, to make his or her income tax refund available to offset a claimant's family tax benefit debt. In such cases, where consent is given, the Commissioner will apply the partner's income tax refund to reduce or extinguish the claimant's family tax benefit debt. The new administrative arrangements for recovering overpayments of family tax benefit, will make it much easier for families to repay a family tax benefit debt. Where it is not possible to recover overpayments of family tax benefit from the taxation system, and for overpayments of child care benefit, these will be recovered by the Family Assistance Office under existing Centrelink arrangements.

Since child care benefit will not be delivered through the tax system, tax refunds and debts will not be applied against child care benefit debts and payments. Also other family assistance overpayments will not be recoverable from child care benefit. However, child care benefit overpayments will be recoverable from family tax benefit or from social security payments.

para.inline: Family Tax Benefit paid through the tax system will be a payment, not a tax rebate or an increase in tax free threshold

speech.para: Although claimants will be able to lodge claims for family tax benefit and receive lump sum and top up payments through the taxation system, the family tax benefit entitlement will not be in the form of a tax rebate or an increase in a person's tax free threshold.

Traditionally, measures like family tax benefit (such as the family tax assistance) have been provided as tax rebates or as an increase in a person's threshold where the rate of family assistance is calculated by the Australian Taxation Office and offset against tax payable.

A similar approach was not adopted for family tax benefit because the administrative mechanism of delivering family tax benefit through a person's income tax assessment would have been very complicated and families would not have been able to benefit from the simpler structure and administrative arrangements of the proposed system (for example, it would not have been possible to ensure that all families receive their correct entitlement regardless of delivery option) which is the main feature of family assistance reform.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
A NEW TAX SYSTEM (FAMILY ASSISTANCE) (CONSEQUENTIAL AND RELATED MEASURES) BILL (NO. 2) 1999

This bill accompanies the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Bill 1999, the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Consequential and Related Measures) Bill (No. 1) 1999 and the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Bill 1999. Together, they will facilitate the introduction of the new family assistance package from 1 July 2000.
The bill:

amends a number of Commonwealth acts that refer to concepts and terms that are relevant under the existing family assistance structure and repeal or amend the references to reflect the new family assistance regime;
provides for the appropriate calculation of family tax benefit part A for those recipients in receipt of income support (or whose partners receive income support);

allows the use or disclosure of information by or between the three agencies involved in the transition to the new family assistance regimeâCentrelink, the Australian Taxation Office and the Health insurance Commissionâfor the purpose of identifying shared customers (so that customers receive only one letter about the new arrangements instead of, potentially, three); and
makes some other minor technical amendments.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Brien) adjourned.

talk.start.para: âTonight I ask honourable senators and others listening to this parliamentary broadcast to imagine a debt-free start for one billion people to the next millennium. This is the aim of the Jubilee 2000 campaign, which is now operating in 60 countries. Jubilee 2000 was started in the United Kingdom in 1990 by a number of individuals who believed that radical action was needed to address the devastating impact of Third World country indebtedness to the world. They identified the year 2000 as a useful focus for a campaign calling for a one-off remission of debt along the lines of the Jubilee year described in the biblical book of Leviticus.

speech.para: The term is used throughout the old and new testaments and other religious teachings. The practice of usury is regarded right throughout as a repugnant term and a repug nant practice towards one's fellow man. The aim of the Jubilee 2000 charter is, firstly, to liberate the poorest nations from the burden of the backlog of unpayable debtâI emphasise that it is unpayable debtâowed by their governments to other countries, to international financial institutions or to commercial banks. It aims to achieve such liberation and a return to sustainable development through an unrepeated one-off remission of unpayable debt of the poorest countries by the year 2000. It also aims to provide a focus and catalyst for harmonising and mobilising international cooperation in supporting actions to promote and achieve the charter's aim. It also seeks to promote understanding among creditor nations that the responsibility for high levels of indebtedness rests with creditors as well as with debtors.

The Jubilee 2000 debt coalition is a practical solution to the problem that has been affecting hundreds of millions of people for over 15 years and will only succeed if we have wide public support. Debt is a crippling fact in the existence and persistence of poverty in so many Third World countries. One billion people are trapped in poverty, and they can do nothing about countries trapped under a mountain of debt that they can never pay back.

In the 1970s, Western banks lent huge sums to Third World countries in the hope that the countries would use the funds to boost exports and to make profits. Unfortunately, interest rates rose rapidly with spiralling debt repayments and the price of primary products often fell to 30 per cent on average, thereby considerably reducing the incomes of Third World countries. Another factor was expenditure on armaments often used to prop up despotic dictators. The result was that the poorest countries in the world began earning less and less and had to pay more and more.

Today, many of the poorest nations are even deeper in debt than they were when they first took out the loans because of the impact of interest. Although they may have repaid much more than the equivalent of the original loan, their total debts continue to rise. The influence of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank on the policies of devel oping countries is immense. Because of this, they too have a key role. In 1992, they stepped in, giving debtor countries more time to pay. Accepting their condition has meant that Third World country governments had even less to spend on their own people.

In Africa as a whole, for example, four times more is spent on interest than on the health care system. In the world's 37 poorest countries, spending per person has gone down 50 per cent on health and 25 per cent on education. In Tanzania, where 40 per cent of people die before the age of 35, debt repayments are six times more than spending on health care.

Jubilee 2000 proposes to celebrate the new millennium by cancelling the unpayable debts of the world's poorest nations. They have worked with economists, business people, politicians, diplomats and aid agencies to design a practical proposal balancing the interests of both the debtors as well as the creditors. So the Jubilee 2000 plan is to identify the poorest debt burdened countries and to calculate the debt of each country that could never be repaid. They would then negotiate conditions to remove this debt on a country by country basis, ensuring that the world would benefit.

In arriving at this decision to remit the burden of the backlog of unpayable debts to the poorest countries, arbitrators would take into account for each debtor country that country's probity, economic management, social policies and human rights record. Debt remission would be made conditional upon governments utilising the financial resources that become available for investment in basic human needs. Targets for improving access to primary health, basic education, water and sanitation will be established along with the costs of meeting them. The debts would be cancelled by the end of the year 2000 as a once-off celebration of the millennium.

Supporters are indeed wide ranging, including the Australian Catholic Social Justice Council, the Baptist churches of Australia, Caritas Australia, Community Aid Abroad, the International Federation of Free Trade Unions, the International Union of Physicians, World Vision and many more. International patrons include Susan George, the Associate Director of the Transnational Institute, and Desmond Tutu, the former Archbishop of Capetown. Australian patrons boast the Most Reverend Keith Rainer, the Archbishop of Melbourne; the Anglican Primate of Australia; Professor Clifford Hughes from the Department of Surgery at the University of Sydney; and the much respected Reverend Tim Costello, who is incidentally the brother of Australia's Treasurer, the Hon. Peter Costello.

Over 35,000 children die each year from hunger related causes. One and a half billion of the world's population live on less than $1 per day. I believe that we could all help by making donations to Jubilee 2000 and by telling others about Jubilee 2000, including its aims.

I also take this opportunity to ask Western governments, including our own, that are not prepared to go to the full extent of writing off the debt to make a gesture of concern and goodwill and at least use this important occasion to perhaps venture even a small or a token write-off of part of the debt. This would be a great gesture. In fact, the write-off is not as unrealistic as some might think, given the almost impossible position of so many of these nations that are not really in a position to pay off that debt in any case. Why not write off a portion of it as a gesture of goodwill in celebration of the 2000 millennium?

talk.start.para: âIt is opportune to be able to rise this evening to address the Senate in regard to some rural and regional information technology challenges in particular. It is opportune for several reasons, including recent media reports which listed the world's richest people according to Forbes magazine. Few would be surprised that Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, gets a guernsey heading the list, but of particular interest was the inclusion of a Japanese businessman, worth an estimated $9.77 billion, who evidently has a larger proportion of the Internet economy than any other. It is amazing, considering that 10 years ago the industry was virtually unheard of and certainly would not have been viewed as being capable of generating such an enormous amount of wealth.

speech.para: All around the world, individuals, companies and countries are grappling with issues surrounding an industry with this capacity, and Australia is no exception. It is especially true that Australia has the potential, as my colleague Senator Tierney pointed out earlier this year in a speech in the chamber, to `become the information hub of South-East Asia'. Look at Australia's take-up of technologyâ1.27 million Australian households were online last year, an increase of almost 50 per cent in 12 months. That equates to 4.2 million Australian adults having access to the web, making it the third-highest per capita user of the Internet after Finland and the United States. It equates to 4.2 million Australians having access to a range of services, information sources and retail outlets through e-commerce which previously were less accessible.

E-commerce is without doubt a growth area, but it is not the only element of the growth of the information economy with which we should concern ourselves. There is a plethora of issues associated with the Internet and other innovations which need to be dealt with for Australia to make the most from these emerging industries and technologies. One of the most important challenges is to ensure that all Australians, especially those across rural and regional areas, can benefit from these innovations. We should remember that, whilst all Australians face particular challenges in incorporating new technologies into their lives or their businesses, those in rural and regional areas often face greater and more varied challenges.

In reading some of the range of literature that abounds in this growing area, I looked at an article from an edition of the Economic Development Review in 1993. In an article entitled `Rural economic development using information age technology' the authors commented on what they described as the `potential to alleviate rurality as a barrier to job creation' as a result of the manner in which new technologies can overcome issues of geographic location. There is no doubt that this is a true statement. The potential of the Internet and e-commerce to make distance almost irrelevant is enormous, but it is up to those directing the growth of these areas to ensure that the benefits are enjoyed by all.

When the West reportâthe government's review of higher education financing and policyâwas released last year, there was much discussion of the use of technology in education. The report noted the potential and increasing role that technologies such as the Internet might play in furthering education. There is enormous benefit to be gained from the Net in terms of breaking down problems of access to education. The possibilities are endless. That raises one of the most pressing challenges in relation to rural and regional use of ITâthat of ensuring that access to the necessary technologies that will allow them to benefit fully from such innovations. It can be as simple as ensuring access to a computer and a telephone line, but it is also about issues that relate to telecommunications and education. Those issues are magnified by the challenges of distance and isolation.
It is not restricted to Australia. In the United States, President Clinton has raised similar concerns and committed the US government to:

. . . hook up every school and every library in this country . . . to the Internet and to make sure that all the schools and all the libraries in the smallest, poorest rural areas and the most densely populated poor urban areas . . . will all be able to afford to use this invaluable service.

Access to technology is not the only challenge facing our increasingly technological world. Ensuring that people have access to information technologies and that they also have the understanding and the motivation to utilise those technologies is just as important. Everybody knows that a computer is useless unless the people sitting in front of them know how to use them and, most importantly, know how to use them to their advantage.

In a report on Australian IT and rural development in the Bulletin of the American Society for Information Science, comment was made of the enthusiasm with which Australians have embraced innovations as simple as mobile phones or VCRs, but there was also a reference to the `relatively low adoption'âin this case, by farmersâ`of computer technology, particularly in comparison to their urban business counterparts'. The point was made that international developments across a range of areas indicate that it would be beneficial for Australian primary producers to utilise new technologies. The challenge for government is to ensure that those in rural and regional areas are motivated by the benefit that they may derive from the use of technologies, understand how to implement them in an appropriate manner and have access to what is required to effect that implementation.

As rapidly as the technologies have become available, there have been individuals and organisations seeking to deal with challenges specific to bringing those advances to rural and regional areas. Most importantly, there have been those who have sought to meet such challenges, not just in relation to economic gains which might be made but also in relation to social gains.

I have referred previously in the Senate to an organisation called Reach Out, which has been focusing solidly on the challenge of providing online advice to young Australians who might be at risk of suicide. Triple J listeners have heard all about Reach Out and recent listeners in particular will be familiar with the Reach Out Rural and Regional Tour which has been occurring recently. The big RORRT, as the project has become known, involves Reach Out representatives travelling across the state to schools, TAFEs and youth centres promoting the organisation and the benefits of Net access for those young people who might require their services. Reach Out also plans to provide free Internet access terminals in different parts of the state, to be accessed by those who might not have ready access in other places.

The coalition have recognised many of the challenges that I have outlined, and we have implemented a number of initiatives and programs aimed at ensuring more equitable application of IT across the country on a broader level. One of the important initiatives was holding a series of regional summits. The summits were launched in conjunction with the release of a policy paper, `Towards an Australian strategy for the information economy.' Many summits, including one in Penrith in greater Western Sydney, where I am based, were conducted across the country throughout last year, and there are plans to hold several more. They are a crucial way of ensuring that regional communities explore the opportunities and the benefits that are to be gained from the Internet and the emerging online economy, hand in hand with the government and the National Office for the Information Economy.

Another significant initiative is the Networking the Nation program, which will ensure that Australians can enjoy the benefits of improved and increasingly varied telecommunications services. The government realised that gaps between the quality and cost of these services in metropolitan and non-metropolitan Australia needed to be addressed and introduced a program to fund increased telecommunications infrastructure across the country and specifically in rural and regional Australia. Funding is open to a range of projects, including those that focus on the provision of one-off infrastructure development, those that trial new innovative technologies, and those that involve assisting communities in identifying needs for particular telecommunications services and uses as an element of an overall project. They might focus on, for example, improving access by removing the STD charge for rural and remote access to the Internet, promoting awareness of online services, providing training, or even providing assistance for start-up or relocation and training costs of establishing communication network assistance services.

As I have suggested, the government have recognised, in a number of areas, the specific needs of rural and regional Australia in regard to information technologies and, through Networking the Nation, aim to ensure that individual communities can reap the benefits available through new technology.

It is worth while noting briefly the breadth of projects that have been funded under Networking the Nation. In the latest round of grants, announced on 1 June, a diversity of projects received funding. For example, Reach Out, the organisation to which I referred earlier, received a sum for Reach Out Bush Network, to build technology resources for young people in rural areas across New South Wales. In my region of greater Western Sydney, TRI Community Exchange received support to develop a comprehensive and dynamic regional intranet and associated training for the community services sector, which will be extended to 12 local government areas in central western New South Wales. In other areas of the state, the projects have been just as impressive. In Cobar, the Cobar Community Development Station Inc. received funding to set up an Internet cafe, with the aim of providing Internet training and awareness raising for business and social use.

This is technology which has the capacity to deal with the worldwide population and economic drift towards major cities that has been occurring for most of this century. It may even address some of that trend, and addressing that would allow rural areas to compete with urban areas on a level footing across a range of issues. How we as a government, but particularly as a nation, approach these emerging challenges will be the measure of how successful we are in the information age.

talk.start.para: âJust 24 hours ago, this Senate passed the bill which will allow the further 16.6 per cent sale of Telstra. That will deliver, to rural and regional Australia in particular, a $1 billion social bonus, and that is undoubtedly welcomed by those living in regional areas of Australia. In particular, my home state of Tasmania has received a generous, albeit much needed, contribution from that social bonus. The mobile phone access and computer access for regional areas, particularly in my home state of Tasmania, is most welcome.

speech.para: I believe people are entitled to ask why the Labor senators and the Greens senator from Tasmania voted against these proposalsâproposals which include the important upgrading of the Tasmanian Athletics Centre, where the facilities were, quite frankly, of Third World standard. Approximately 20,000 school children per annum access those facilities, but Labor and Greens senators wanted to deny those Tasmanian school children the right to those proper and decent facilities. The Bill Barwick International Athletics Centre, as it will be called, will receive a major boost with a contribution of $600,000. Similarly, the Tasmanian people are entitled to ask why Labor senators and the Greens senator from Tasmania voted against the proposal which delivers the sealing of the Flinders Island airstripâan important matter for those people living on Flinders Island.

Indeed, the question has to be asked: why did the member for Bass also vote against this proposal? The question can also be asked: why did the members for Braddon and Bass and the Labor senators from Tasmania seek to deny the people of King and Flinders Islands a proper mobile phone service? Sure, they enjoy the mobile phone service, living in Launceston and Burnie in my home state, and when they come up to Canberra they can always use their mobile phones. But the people who live on King Island and Flinders Island in Bass Strait do not have such a privilege, and these Labor members and senators would seek to deny them that opportunity.

The most bizarre thing of all is the Greens senator's opposition to the $25 million boost to the Natural Heritage Trust funding for Tasmania. If one is committed to the environment, as we are led to believe the Greens senator is, one has to ask: why is it that he would seek to deny the Tasmanian environment $25 million worth of repairs? The reason, quite simply, is that his left-wing ideology of government ownership is a lot more important to him than the bottom line of fixing the environment. One could also ask: why is it that the Labor members from Tasmania, the Labor senators and the Greens senator opposed the extra coverage that will be provided for SBS television to remote areas, including areas in Tasmania?

There is no doubt that this package will be of major significance to Tasmania. It is a major boost. But when the test came, Labor Party members and senators from Tasmania slavishly followed the party line rather than being concerned about the best interests of the people whom they are elected to represent. In recent times we have had a Labor campaign seeking to deflect from these excellent outcomes for Tasmania by suggesting that there have been job losses in Telstra. There have been no job losses in Tasmania in relation to Telstra. The numbers are pretty well even; indeed, there may have been a slight growth.

But all that aside, the simple fact is that any rearrangement of jobs within Telstra is a function of the competition policy which the previous Labor government introduced. It has nothing to do with privatisation. Indeed, with our policies of pursuing privatising and seeking to make the telecommunications industry even more efficient, there are today now more jobs in telecommunications than there were when we first came into government. So the furphy that the Labor senators are trying to introduce into this debate is something that they need to live with, because in fact it is a function of competition that they themselves whilst in government introduced into the marketplace.

I am, along with the vast majority of my fellow Tasmanians, absolutely delighted with the package that the federal government was able to put together in relation to the sale of Telstra and the $1 billion social bonus from which Tasmania benefits so greatly. Yesterday I had the opportunity to put on the record, via ABC radio to listeners in New South Wales, the reason that Tasmania is so deserving of extra funding from a social bonus. It should be remembered in this place that, as a result of decisions taken by former Labor governments, a major power development in my home state was blocked, then the development of a major pulp mill was blocked by federal Labor and 40 per cent of our landmass has now been locked up as part of the world heritage areas introduced by Labor.

Those three decisions, designed to get Green preferences on the mainland, have had devastating social and economic consequences for my fellow Tasmanians and the economy of my home state. Unfortunately when you take those decisions it takes some time to wash through, but the people of Tasmania are now suffering with population decline and the highest rate of unemployment in the nation. We were told that we would never need that extra power supply. We now have a strange twist of politics with the Labor Deputy Premier coming up to Canberra seeking federal assistance to get a gas pipeline across Bass Strait to assist with the power needs of Tasmania. That is the problem of a lack of forward planning and short-term decision making by federal Labor trying to get Green preferences at the expense of the Tasmanian people, and it is now having a devastating impact on my home state. It is therefore appropriate, when moneys are freed up through this sale of Telstra, that from that social bonus an extra portion be paid to Tasmania to make up for those horrendous decisions taken by the Labor Party against my home state since 1983.

The people of Tasmania welcome this package overwhelmingly. They are absolutely devastated to think that Labor senators and Labor members of the House of Representativesâto a man and womanâvoted against this package when they know the desperate need for Tasmania to be provided with this money which has been so well targeted. These are initiatives that show that a lot of thought went into the package and identified needs and possibilities for Tasmania to become a more self-sustaining economy. I, for one, welcome the announcements that were made over the weekend and the passage of the further partial sale of Telstra by this Senate yesterday evening, and the people of Tasmania are very pleased by the decisions taken by this Senate and the federal Liberal government.

talk.start.para: âI was not intending to speak this evening, but I think there should be some analysis of some of the comments that have been made by Senator Abetz and other government senators about the Telstra package that was negotiated by Senator Harradine. Let me say at the outset that, when I was first given to understand the nature of the package, it seemed to be a package with a lot of merits for my state. But I guess I, like a lot of other people, can be dazzled at first glance by the impact of the package of measures which have been negotiated and, without thinking the matter through, come to a quick and probably wrong conclusion. I was startled to hear one of my colleagues from the other side of the chamber tonight talk about the package in terms that suggested that, within five years, its value would be greatly diminished. Looking at that package in light of those comments, I had to come to the view that that senator was, to a great extent, correct.

speech.para: I am concerned about a number of aspects of the package, and I am particularly concerned about the way that it is received by other Australians. I think it is unfortunate that it has been suggested that this is the package that will make Tasmania an intelligent island. I was heartened by comments in the Financial Review today which suggested that the island was indeed already an intelligent island. The fact of the matter is that a lot of the people who have gained their qualifications have had to move to mainland Australia to obtain employment which is commensurate with their skills and education. That is the problem: not making Tasmania an intelligent island. So I say that that is an unfortunate epithet.

I am very concerned about the way the package has been received elsewhere. The editorial in today's West Australian is edifying, and I want to quote from that. It says, under the heading `PM in Grubby Vote-Buying Politics':

The Howard Government has resorted to shabby vote-buying to try to secure the passage of its Telstra legislation through the Senate. Its brazen inducements to Tasmanian Independent Senator Brian Harradine to support the sale of a further 16.6 per cent of Telstra reveal an administration driven by the dangerous idea that the end justifies the means. And Senator Harradine seems all too ready to sell his vote if the price is right for Tasmania.

Prime Minister John Howard says Tasmania needs a bit of help because it has the highest unemployment level in Australia and not much industry. That is humbug. If Mr Howard believed that Tasmania needed special help, why did he not provide it earlier? He left it to the eve of the Senate vote on the Telstra sale to promise a special deal for Tasmania. And he has made the extra money for Tasmania conditional on the Senate voting for the sale proposal. Again, if Tasmania's needs are so overwhelmingly pressing, then it should be helped regardless of what happens to Telstra.
Quite right.

talk.start.para: âDo you oppose the deal?

âSenator Abetz is interjecting. I listened to him without interruption and I would ask him for the same courtesy. Today in the Hobart Mercury , on page 18, the editorial, which supports the package, says:

speech.para: Federal Opposition Leader Kim Beazley is absolutely correct. The Telstra sale deal stitched up by Tasmanian Independent Senator Brian Harradine with the Federal Government is shameless pork-barrelling. The deal will probably upset most mainlanders but it will delight the majority of Tasmanians.

There are quite a number of articles in today's papers about the deal, and almost without exception the comments from outside of Tasmania are deprecatory about the deal, particularly the proportion of the social bonus that Tasmania has achieved. I do not oppose any of the initiatives per se. Given that you are going to put together a package of measures, some of them, I suspect, if there was going to be a proportionate distribution of the social bonus, would have gone to Tasmania, though obviously the proportion is in excess of its population base.

Let me ask these rhetorical questions, and perhaps Senator Harradine will come into the chamber and answer them. In considering this package of measures, if Senator Harradine was to obtain consideration for his support for the legislation, why was consideration not given, for example, to a proposal that the government legislate to make Bass Strait part of the national highway system? A delegation was in Canberra today, I believeâbecause of my duties I was unable to be involved in any way in its proposalâseeking the support of the federal government for making Bass Strait part of the national highway system. What could be a more enduring job creation system for Tasmania, strengthening its tourism potential and giving benefits to members of the Australian public from mainland Australia to come to Tasmania and benefits for Tas manians to leave the state, temporarily or permanently, by sea highway at no more cost than the cost of driving on the national highway system from one state to another in the rest of Australia? What could have been more valuable than that?

talk.start.para: âWe have got that.

âSenator Abetz suggests that we have that. I wonder why the delegation was here today. I do not think you know what you are talking about, because we clearly have not got it, and that is why the delegation was here in Canberra today.
âNo, it is the passenger cars.

âOf course it is the passenger crossing of Bass Strait, and it is clear you do not understand what you are talking about, Senator Abetz. It is the passage of passengers across Bass Strait by sea transport which places Tasmanians and Tasmania at a disadvantage. I guess I am wondering out loud why that was not considered rather than some of the issues that have been considered, needed though they might be. It is a question of priorities.

speech.para: It was suggested in the debate that in lieu of some of these measuresâmeasures which might have a real life of only about five yearsâit would have been more beneficial for Senator Harradine to have picked up Labor's proposal from the last election, which I believe had the endorsement of the Tasmanian people, that the whole of Tasmania be a local call area zone. That would have meant significant savings to business and consumers in Tasmania, and it would not have run out in five years, because the use of the telephone system will certainly continue. It has been estimated that that would make an ongoing saving of $25 million per year for business and the public generally in Tasmania.

I am really asking the rhetorical questions of Senator Harradine, and he may take the opportunity to come in here and talk about whether those matters were considered by him or, if they were not, why they were not. I really do have the concern that, whilst some of these issues appear to have merit at the moment, they may well be issues which do not have the life that some other measures might have had. I do suggest that perhaps getting a benefit for the state of Tasmania of the nature of either of those two initiatives would have been of more value and less likely to draw the criticism that there has been around the country of the deal that Senator Harradine has made with the government. Senator Harradine has no doubt done what he thinks is right. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Christmas Islanders: Repatriation and Resettlement Compensation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 584)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 10 March 1999:

question.para: (1) What has the Howard Government done to compensate and settle the claims of former Christmas Islanders who were re-settled and repatriated from the island to mainland Australia and South-East Asia.

(2) Has the department complied with Australia's international obligations on human rights or has it discriminated against former islanders of Asian origin in their re-settlement and repatriation from Christmas Island.

(3) Considering the compensation made to the South Sea Islanders, Ocean Islanders and Nauru: Why has the Howard Government not compensated the former islanders by government grants, full-time welfare officers, providing funds for building temples of worship or other compensation; and (b) why has the government not granted the former islanders the same status as that of the South Sea Islanders.

(4) Why is the department spending taxpayers funds in defending the claims of former islanders for compensation which the Commonwealth of Australia acknowledged it owed to the islanders in 1958 (letter from Secretary, Department of Territories to the Secretary, Department of External Affairs, 26 September 1958) and in the 1970s (statement in the House of Representatives on 12 April 1973 by the Hon WL Morrison, MP on the future of the Asian residents of Christmas Island and second reading speech by Senator the Hon. RG Withers on the Christmas Island Agreement Bill 1976).

(5) (a) Is the Minister aware that the repatriation and re-settlement of the former islanders to mainland Australia and South-East Asia was in breach of the human rights of the islanders, contrary to the slavery treaties to which Australia is a signatory and in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975; and (b) what is intended to be done to correct this injustice.

(6) Why did the department advise the Department of Territories and Local Government not to set up a scheme of compensation in response to a submission by the islanders to the department on 27 February 1996.

(7) Why is the department continuing to waste taxpayers funds in defending the claims of the former islanders of Asian origin considering the international ramifications and the promises made by the Commonwealth when Australia took over sovereignty of the island in 1958.

(8) Why has the Government not set up a scheme of compensation for former islanders considering the legal, political and public ramifications nationally and internationally which have arisen from the claims of the former islanders.

(9) Does the Government condone racial discrimination against persons of Asian origin in the Territories of Australia, their repatriation without compensation if such persons are Australian citizens or permanent residents and the payment of income and social security benefits substantially less than that allowable under federal awards and legislation.

(10) Is the Department aware of the interest that the claims of the former islanders have raised in South-East Asia, particularly in the ministerial departments of the Governments of Singapore and Malaysia.

(11) For the period between 1957 and 1980 what profits and surplus were received by the Commonwealth of Australia as consolidated revenue or otherwise from the operations of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission, the British Phosphate Commission, their successors or assigns.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) As of 28 February 1999, the Employment Advocate (EA) had a contract with the Wallis Consulting Group Pty Ltd and the department had contracts with Worthington Di Marzio Pty Ltd and Australasian Research Strategies Pty (ARSP). Although the work under the original contract with Worthington Di Marzio Pty Ltd had been completed at that date, the department was negotiating a contract variation for further work. This has now commenced.
(2) The information provided under the contracts is both qualitative and quantitative.
(3) The contract with Wallis Consulting Group Pty Ltd relates to freedom of association.

The contract with Worthington Di Marzio Pty Ltd is to provide research to assist with strategic input and effective evaluation of the communications campaign about reforms to the employment services market.

The contract with ARSP is to obtain information on the drivers behind public attitudes to further workplace reform. The project is based on VISTA values research methodology, ARSP being the sole Australian supplier of this methodology.
(4) Two surveys are being conducted by Wallis Consulting Group Pty Ltd:
* a survey of approximately 1000 employers conducted by telephone and mail questionnaire; and
* a survey of 1000 union members conducted by telephone.

The employer survey is in the form of a self-completed mail survey returned by mail or fax. Prior to the surveys being mailed out to approximately 1000 employers, telephone interviewers called a sample of business establishments (1600 employers) selected at random from the Yellow pages and Dun and Bradstreet's commercial listing to establish the most appropriate person in the company to respond to the survey. Establishments were chosen to fit industry and size criteria (ANZSIC industry codes excluding agriculture, forestry and fishing; 400 small establishments, 300 medium establishments and 300 large establishments). Companies employing one or two people only at a site were excluded from the study.

The union member survey was conducted by telephone with employees at their homes and was run at the same time as the employer survey. The telephone survey method was selected in this instance because postal questionnaires may present difficulties for some employees in relation to literacy and understanding of questions (eg employees who are less educated or for whom English is not their first language).
Polling methods used by Worthington Di Marzio Pty Ltd were focus group discussions, executive depth interviews and telephone interviews.

The ARSP project consists of four stages involving a preliminary focus group phase; in-depth interviewing research; conduct of a survey and benchmarking of findings; and follow-up. The first two stages use qualitative methods and the third and fourth use quantitative methods. The third and fourth stages are optional.
(5) Budgeted cost for Wallis Consulting Group Pty Ltd: $99,270
Budgeted cost for Worthington Di Marzio Pty Ltd: $183,450
Budgeted cost for the ARSP project: $340,000 plus a maximum of $35,000 for travel.

(6) There are no sub-contractors performing work related to the Wallis Consulting Group Pty Ltd or Worthington Di Marzio Pty Ltd. No individual sub-contractors are specified in the contract with ARSP. However, the contract notes that ARSP may sub-contract fieldwork to companies which are members of either Interviewer Quality Control (IQCA) or the Association of Marketing Research Organisations (AMRO).
(7) The contract with Wallis Consulting Group Pty Ltd was let through an open tender process

The original contract with Worthington Di Marzio Pty Ltd was let through a selective tender process with the names of suitable polling organisations supplied by the former Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA).

The contract with ARSP was let through a staged procurement process. The department, on behalf of the Labour Ministers' Council, has established a panel of researchers who are available to undertake workplace relations related research projects including market research. The panel was formed through an open national advertisement. Thirty-four researchers submitted proposals to be part of the panel, including ARSP.

(8) Yes. (a) As described above, the EA has a contract with the Wallis Consulting Group, Melbourne for the purposes described in the answer to part (3) of the question. (b) The services provided are the conduct of two surveys [outlined in answer (4)] and analysis of data to be supplied in report form to the EA. (c) The EA developed the particulars of the services required under the contract. (d) The survey questions were formulated by the Wallis Consulting Group, in consultation with the EA. (e) $99,270.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 23 April 1999:

question.para: With reference to the Jabiluka uranium mine project:
(1) What action has the Australian Government taken, since December 1998, to review all the perceived threats to world heritage and institute necessary protective measures
(2) (a) Who conducted this action; and (b) when.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Australian Government reviewed the potential threats identified by the UNESCO Mission's report on Kakadu and specifically addressed these threats in its report "Australia's Kakadu; Protecting World Heritage" submitted to the World Heritage Committee in April 1999.

The Supervising Scientist conducted a full review and prepared a report addressing the issue of scientific uncertainty which was identified in the UNESCO Mission report. Four consultancies were also commissioned by the Supervising Scientist to address issues of hydrometeorological analysis, climate change analysis, surface water storage, and tailings storage. The Supervising Scientist presented his report to the World Heritage Committee in April 1999.

Environment Australia was involved in a range of activities including developing and conducting a consultancy regarding potential impacts of dust, developing a consultancy on the potential impacts of vibrations, and undertaking an audit of previous anthropological work in the Jabiluka lease area throughout December 1998 to April 1999.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 23 April 1999:

question.para: With reference to the Jabiluka uranium mine project:

(1) What action has the Australian Government taken, since December 1998, to undertake an exhaustive independent review and further risk analysis of all claims of scientific uncertainty relating to the project.
(2) (a) Who conducted this action; and (b) when.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Supervising Scientist undertook a comprehensive review of the claims of scientific uncertainty relating to the Jabiluka project. The executive summary of the report to the World Heritage Committee, which resulted from this review, provides details of the topics, process and findings of the review. A copy of the executive summary has been provided to the honourable senator and additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

(2) (a) The Supervising Scientist undertook the review, drawing on expertise available within his own organisation and expert advice from a number of scientific institutes in Australia. Scientists from the Bureau of Meteorology, the University of Melbourne, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the University of New South Wales were commissioned to prepare reports on specific topics.

(b) The review commenced shortly after the 30 November to 5 December 1998 World Heritage Committee meeting in Kyoto. The report was presented to the World Heritage Centre on 15 April 1999. Copies of the Assessment of the Jabiluka Project, Report of the Supervising Scientist of the World Heritage Committee, Executive Summary are available from the Senate Table Office.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1 and 2) Plans by Energy Resources of Australia (ERA) to expand housing and other infrastructure in Jabiru as a consequence of mining at Jabiluka are being monitored by officers of Environment Australia based in Jabiru.

During the period December 1998âApril 1999 ERA's local housing needs were being met from existing housing stock and at temporary contractor accommodation re-established in Jabiru in 1996. Specific requirements for additional housing for the Jabiluka project have not been finalised and will be dependent on whether the Ranger mill alternative or the Jabiluka mill alternative proceeds as part of the Jabiluka mine development.

In December 1998 ERA announced that production levels at Ranger uranium mine would be reduced effective 31 March 1999 and that there would be a small reduction in staff numbers at the Ranger mine. The Hon. Bob Collins, Chair of the Kakadu Region Social Impact Study (KRSIS) Implementation Team, is having on-going discussions with ERA about housing in Jabiru, and the social impacts on Aboriginal people of development in Jabiru, as a part of his KRSIS work.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 23 April 1999:

question.para: With reference to the Jabiluka uranium mine project:

(1) What action has the Australian Government taken, since December 1998, to ensure that mechanisms in place will effectively limit the expansion of Jabiru to prevent any threat to the World Heritage property.
(2) (a) Who conducted this action; and (b) when.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: No action has been taken to implement new arrangements to control the development of the township of Jabiru (within Kakadu National Park), as there has been no need to do so.

The township of Jabiru has been developed in line with the recommendation of the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry that the town be established within Kakadu National Park and be subject to planning principles set out in the Kakadu plan of management. The inclusion of the town in the park was a specific measure taken so that the Director of National Parks and Wildlife could ensure that the impacts of the town and its residents on the surrounding park environment are as small as possible.

On 9 March 1999 a new Kakadu plan of management came into effect. This plan details the steps that have to be taken before the Director of National Parks and Wildlife can approve any amendment to the town lease, the implementation of a new or amended town plan, any change in land tenure or land use and any construction or expansion of tourism or other infrastructure development in the town.

The plan requires that the Director make an assessment of the expected positive and negative impacts of any proposed change on the park environment and consults with relevant traditional owners and the Northern Land Council about the proposed changes. The Director is also required to take account of the findings of the Kakadu Region Social Impact Study.

Proposals also have to be referred to the Kakadu Board of Management for consideration in accordance with the Board's statutory decision-making functions. A majority of the members of the Kakadu Board of Management are Aboriginal people representing the traditional owners of Kakadu National Park.

The Kakadu plan of management specifically provides that the Director can only approve changes to Jabiru where these are consistent with the wishes of Aboriginal people and where the net benefit of any change outweighs any detriment to the cultural and natural environment of the park.

answer.para: The Australian Government supports the ongoing best practice management of introduced species in Kakadu National Park. Under the Plan of Management, there are a number of ongoing actions to maintain best practice management, including:
* Mimosa and Salvinia program;
* Paragrass programs; and
* Ongoing information exchange between ERA Environmental Services and Parks Australia in relation to feral pests in the Park.
Specific actions relating to the Jabiluka mine site, include:
* Ongoing training for ERA staff and technical advice to ERA on weed management provided by Parks Australia;
* Site inspections in February and March 1999 by Parks Australia North dealing with weed management issues on the Jabiluka mine site; and
* A review of the Draft Weeds Management Plan for the Jabiluka mine site by Parks Australia North. The review is presently under way.

(1) Is the Minister aware that, in the report, Mr Reeves identified as Royalty Associations incorporated Aboriginal associations that receive monies from mining operations and other such sources as park entrance fees.

(2) Is the Minister aware that, on p.347 of the report, Mr Reeves states, `the requirements for royalty Associations to account for their expenditure are wholly inadequate for the purpose of revealing the ultimate purposes to which these monies have been put'.

(3) Is the Minister aware that one such royalty Association is Gundjehmi Aboriginal Corporation which at March 1999 had 27 members and is incorporated under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act and receives monies as a result of the royalties paid by the Ranger uranium mining operations at Jabiru in the Northern Territory.

(4) Is the Minister aware that Mr Blacker, an auditor with KR Blacker and Associates, qualified his audit of the 1996-97 financial year accounts of the Gundjehmi Corporation by expressing concern about inadequate documentation for travel expenses which together with travel allowances totalled over $59 000.

(5) Is the Minister aware that Mr Blacker was unable to verify the distribution of members' entitlements, which totalled $626 000 in the 1995/96 financial year and $87 000 in the 1996/97 financial year.

(6) Is the Minister aware that the financial statements for the year ended 30 June 1998 reveal the following features: (a) although the association received over $600,000 in royalty receipts and Ranger rental and has over $760,000 in liquid assets, there was no distribution of member entitlements; (b) the association of 27 members in 1998 paid wages of over $270,000 and incurred travel expenses of almost $100,000; and (c) advertising expenses increased 30 times to $37 000, consultancy fees increased 30 times to $73 000, motor vehicle expenses increased five times to $30 000 and repairs and maintenance increased 60 times to $43 000.

(7) Will the Minister call on the registrar appointed under the Aboriginal Council and Associations Act to investigate the affairs of the Gundjehmi Aboriginal corporation to ensure that the corporation is applying its funds to their proper purposes and complying with the law and its rules and constitution.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, I am aware that Mr Reeves did indeed, in his report, identify incorporated Aboriginal bodies receiving mining royalty equivalents and revenue from other activities as Royalty Associations.

(2) Yes, Mr Reeves did make that finding. However, it should be noted that this finding is not necessarily supported by the government and that the review conducted by Mr Reeves is currently being inquired into by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Any Government decisions about the findings and recommendations of Mr Reeves will await the completion of that inquiry.

(3) I am advised that the Gundjehmi Aboriginal Corporation was incorporated on 14 July 1995 under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976. Financial records lodged by the corporation with the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations also confirm that it has received income derived from mining royalty equivalents. Those royalty equivalents were derived from the Ranger uranium mine in the Northern Territory.

(4) The Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations has advised that audited financial information for 1996/97 provided by the corporation, prepared by KR Blacker and Associatesâa Darwin based firm of Management and Taxation Consultants, contain a minor qualification with respect to travel expenses. The auditor expressed his qualification in the following terms:
"travel expenses need to be better documented. . . ."
The auditor also commented in relation to the qualification that he:
"accepted assurances from the executive that system changes have been adopted".
The Registrar has confirmed that the audit report for the corporation for the following year (ie 1997/98) did not contain any qualification relating to travel expenses.

(5) The Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations has advised that the corporation's financial records for 1995/96 record $626,300 as being distributed to members. The corporation's auditor commented that:

"the trading records declare a substantial amount of funds were distributed to members of the corporation. While it would appear that most of these distributions are well documented it is not practical for the auditor to verify the entitlement or receipt of those distributions". I accept the executive offices (sic) assurance that there are no disputes or discrepancies relating to these distributions".
In the view of the Registrar, the comments by the auditor do not constitute a qualification with regard to the distributions to members.
With regard to the corporation's distributions to members in 1996/97 of $87,001.94, the auditor qualified his report by stating that:
"the scope of the audit did not verify distribution of entitlements and I accept the assurance of the executive that there are no disputes or discrepancies regarding these matters"

The Registrar has advised that the auditor's qualification relates primarily to the coverage of the audit that did ". . . not verify distribution. . . " rather than the auditor being ". . . unable to verify the distribution. . . " as asked in your question.
(6) The Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations has advised me that the corporation's audit report for 1997/98 confirms that:
(a) the corporation received $603,279.64 in royalty and rental receipts. There was no record of monies distributed to members.
(b) The corporation paid $272,806.57 in wages and expended $99,876.72 on travel expenses and allowances.
(c) The Corporation expended $37,076.15 on advertising. The corporation also expended $30,921.09 on motor vehicles expenses.
The Registrar also advises that the increases in expenditure incurred by the corporation over those of the previous year, although substantial, did not attract any adverse comment by the auditor.

(7) I have noted the Senator's question and point out that it is the Registrar's prerogative to discharge his obligations under the Aboriginal Councils sand Associations Act 1976. The Registrar has advised that the Corporation is in compliance with its reporting obligations under the Aboriginal Councils sand Associations Act 1976. Furthermore, the audit report contained only one qualification that would appear to be unrelated to the questions asked.

The Registrar has advised that having regard to the most recent audit report, and in particular the absence of significant qualifications, the current compliance by the corporation with its reporting requirements, and in the absence of recent or specific allegations against the corporation, the Registrar advises that there is insufficient cause to justify an investigation of the corporation's affairs.

The Registrar has given me an assurance that, should any allegations or specific concerns relating to the affairs corporation be forthcoming, he would take appropriate action consistent with his statutory responsibilities under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976.

question.para: For all the work funded from the $30 million allocated through the Natural Heritage Trust to the National Land and Water Resources Audit, can the following information be provided: (a) the title of the project; (b) the aim of the project and a brief description, including the geographical area to which it relates; (c) the organisations or individuals carrying out the project; (d) the amount allocated to the project and its starting and finishing dates; and (e) references to any published reports or outcomes from the project.
